questions.question: Hematuria in children is defined as the presence of at least 5 RBCs per high power field in uncentrifuged urine.
questions.explanation: The presence of at least 5 RBCs per high power field in uncentrifuged urine is a common definition of hematuria in children.

questions.question: An 11-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of multipleepisodes of passing blood in the urine. Which of the following condition is not associated withthis symptom?
questions.explanation: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with acute-onset microscopic hematuria notrecurrent gross hematuria.Causes of recurrent gross hematuria:•Alport's syndrome: hereditary nephritis• Thin glomerular basement membrane disease•IgA nephropathy: Berger's disease• Idiopathic hypercalciuria/hyperuricosuria• Sickle cell nephropathy (papillary necrosis)

questions.question: A 6-year-old girl with urinary complaints was brought to the hospital by her parents. Onfurther enquiry, they mention a history of skin lesions 5 weeks back. Low C3 levels are foundduring her investigations. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals a "lumpy-bumpy" patternof immunoglobulin and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane. Whichof the following is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Urinary complaints with a history of skin lesions (pyoderma) point towards a likely diagnosis ofglomerulonephritis. Results of complement study and immunofluorescence microscopy alsocorrelate with this diagnosis. Frothy urine is due to proteinuria, which is a feature of nephroticsyndrome.Classic features of nephritic syndrome/glomerulonephritis:• Cola coloured urine (hematuria)• Oliguria•Hypertension• Facial or body edema512

questions.question: Akshay, accompanied by his father, presents to the OPD with complaints of cola-colouredurine and facial puffiness for 3 days. He has a history of fever with a sore throat that resolved2 weeks back. Which of the following findings is consistent with the diagnosis ofpost-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?

options.A: C3 level increases and ASO level increases
options.B: C3 level decreases and ASO level increases
options.C: C3 level decreases and ASO level decreases
options.D: C3 level increases and ASO level decreases

questions.explanation: C3 level decreases and ASO level increases in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).Acute PSGN is a classic example of an acute nephritic syndrome characterized by the suddenonset of gross hematuria, oedema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It follows infection of thethroat or skin by certain nephritogenic strains of group A ẞ-hemolytic streptococci-• 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or• 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

questions.question: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hematuria associated withglomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation: Hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis is typically painless.Hematuria from within the glomerulus is often associated with brown-, cola-, or tea-colored urine.Urine analysis reveals RBC casts and deformed urinary RBCs (particularly acanthocytes).

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy presents with decreased urine output for 3 days. He has a history of sorethroat 2 weeks back. On examination, he is hypertensive with pitting pedal oedema. Thediagnosis is concluded as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Which of the following istrue about this condition?

options.D: Renal biopsy is indicated in severe impairment of renal function.

questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette of oliguria, pedal edema and hypertension point towardsglomerulonephritis. Severe impairment of renal functions in a background of post-streptococcalglomerulonephritis is an indication for renal biopsy.Indications for renal biopsy in glomerulonephritis:• Presence of acute renal failure or nephrotic syndrome•Absence of evidence of streptococcal infection• Presence of normal complement levels• Persistence of hematuria and proteinuria, diminished renal function, and/or a low C3 level formore than 2 months after the disease onsetSerum triglycerides (Option A) are elevated in nephrotic syndrome, not in nephritic syndrome.The acute phase generally resolves within 6 to 8 weeks. Although urinary protein excretion andhypertension usually normalize by 4-6 wk after onset, microscopic hematuria (Option B) canpersist for 1 to 2 years after the initial presentation.The serum C3 level (Option C) is significantly reduced in >90% of patients in the acute phase,and returns to normal 6-8 weeks after onset.

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy with a previously diagnosed renal disorder is brought to your OPD with thefollowing reports for a second opinion. What is the likely diagnosis?503
questions.explanation: The findings mentioned are characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).Findings in PSGN:513• Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increasein the mesangial matrix. Polymorphoneutrophil (PMN) infiltration in the early stages.•⚫ Immunofluorescence: "Lumpy-bumpy" deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on theglomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium.• Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or "humps," are observed on the epithelial side ofthe GBM.The image given below depicts the microscopic picture of PSGN. It shows glomerularhypercellularity due to intracapillary leukocytes. Neutrophilic infiltration is present and is markedwith purple hematoxylin stain (black arrows).Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritisHypercellularglomerulusProliferatingcapillariesOther options:Idiopathic rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis:•Light microscopy: Crescents develop in several forms of glomerulonephritis (are a characteristicresponse to the deposition of fibrin in Bowman's space)• Electron microscopy: No deposits•Focal segmental glomerulonephritis:Light microscopy: Focal sclerotic lesions• Electron microscopy: Foot process fusionMinimal change disease:•Light microscopy: Normal• Electron microscopy Effacement of foot process

questions.question: An 8-year-old boy presented with cola-coloured urine, decreased urine output, and facialpuffiness for 3 days. He had a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. On examination, he isfound to be hypertensive. His serum C3 levels are low and ASO levels are increased. What isthe appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation: 514The features of hematuria, oliguria, facial oedema present with a history of skin infection pointstowards the diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Results of complementstudy and ASO levels also support this diagnosis. Supportive conservative therapy is the best stepin the management of PSGN.Management of PSGN is directed at treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodiumrestriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension.Although a 10-day course of systemic antibiotic therapy with penicillin is recommended to limitthe spread of the nephritogenic organisms, antibiotic therapy does not a ect the natural history ofacute PSGN.Note: Steroids and cyclosporine are not used in the management of PSGN.

questions.question: Sarthak, a 7-year-old boy, was brought to the emergency department by his parents withcomplaints of blurred vision and severe headache since today morning. They mentioned anepisode of fits 2 hours back following which they rushed him to the hospital. On furtherenquiry, it was elicited that the child had decreased urine output for 5 days with cola colouredurine. He was hypertensive with bilateral pitting pedal oedema. The doctor remembered thatSarthak has a glomerular disorder warranting him multiple prior ward admissions and hisexisting condition could be a possible complication of the same. All of the following arecommonly seen as a complication of this disorder except-
questions.explanation: The given features of oliguria, hematuria, pedal edema and hypertension are likely ofglomerulonephritis. The complication of hypertensive encephalopathy is seen in this case due tosymptoms of seizure, blurred vision and severe headache. Hyperkalemia and left ventricularfailure are also common complications of glomerulonephritis while bleeding diasthesis is not acomplication of glomerulonephritis.Acute complications of glomerulonephritis result from hypertension and acute renal dysfunction-• Hypertension is seen in 60% of patients and is sometimes associated with hypertensiveencephalopathy and intracranial bleeding.• Acute renal failure can occur, which may require treatment with dialysis.Other potential complications include the following:•Heart failure• Hyperkalemia•.Hyperphosphatemia• Hypocalcemia• Hyponatremia• Acidosis• Seizures• Uremia

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria 2 days after an episode of diarrhoea. Theserum C3 levels are normal. Light microscopy demonstrates focal and segmental mesangialproliferation and increased mesangial matrix in the glomerulus. What is the probable504diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Gross hematuria following a gastrointestinal infection, associated with normal C3 levels, in amale patient is suggestive of immunoglobulin A nephropathy (Berger nephropathy).•IgA nephropathy is the most common chronic glomerular disease in children.515• Focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix are seen in theglomerulus.• It is characterized by a predominance of IgA within mesangial glomerular deposits in theabsence of systemic disease.•It is seen more often in males.• Gross hematuria occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinalinfection (in contrast to the long latency period observed in acute post-streptococcalglomerulonephritis).•• It can be associated with loin pain.Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy (help to distinguish this disorder from PSGN).• Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic value because they are elevated in only a few paediatricpatients.

questions.question: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tractinfection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury inthis condition?
questions.explanation: The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgAantibodies in the mesangial cell.Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseasescharacterized by the deposition of immune complexes.Mesangial cell diseases:• IgA nephropathy• IgM nephropathy•Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis• Class II lupus nephritis• Diabetic nephropathyNote: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upperrespiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks isobserved in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.question: ANCA-positive, pauci-immune glomerulonephritis include-
questions.explanation: Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinctforms:• Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis)• Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)⚫ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome (CSS)•516Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immunecomplex deposition.ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affectingsmall-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity foreither proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO).Absence or paucity of immune complex deposits in vessel walls is very characteristic, hence thename "pauci-immune vasculitis."

questions.question: An 8-year-old girl presented with complaints of cough, hemoptysis and swelling of both legs.Urinalysis was notable for hematuria and proteinuria. Serum anti-GBM antibodies werepositive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The diagnosis is Goodpasture disease (anti-GBM antibody disease). Anti-glomerular basementmembrane (anti-GBM) antibodies are diagnostic."Goodpasture syndrome" is characterized by pulmonary haemorrhage and glomerulonephritisand "Goodpasture disease" is used for those patients with glomerulonephritis, pulmonaryhemorrhage, and anti-GBM antibodies. It is caused due to autoantibodies directed against type IVcollagen, which is present in the alveoli and glomerular basement membrane. Currently, thepreferred term for both conditions is "anti-GBM antibody disease".•Other options along with the pathogenesis of glomerular diseases:IgA nephropathy- mesangial cell disease due to immune complex deposition• Minimal change disease- epithelial cell disease due to flattening of podocytes

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture.Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Microscopic analysis of his renalbiopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following finding?
questions.explanation: The boy in this clinical scenario has characteristic features of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP).The renal biopsy in this patient will show mesangial proliferation with mesangial deposition ofIgA• HSP is a common small-vessel vasculitis in childhood.•It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominalpain.•About half the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomaticmicroscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.• The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash•⚫ The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymericimmunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

questions.question: All are features of Alport syndrome except-
questions.explanation: 517Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive hearing loss) is a feature of Alport syndrome(AS).AS or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease (most have X-linked inheritance) caused bymutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen, a major component of the basementmembranes.Clinical features of Alport syndrome:• Hematuria: All patients have asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. Recurrent episodes of grosshematuria may be seen 1-2 days after an upper respiratory infection.•• Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive)Ocular abnormalities: anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, corneal erosions• Proteinuria: Progressive proteinuria, often exceeding 1 g/ 24 hrs, is common by the 2nd decadeof life.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy presented with dark coloured urine. Urinalysis was notable for macroscopichematuria and heavy proteinuria. His father is a known case of Alport syndrome. What defectis responsible for this condition?506
questions.explanation: A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible forAlport syndrome.Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may beautosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

questions.question: All of the following syndromes are associated with renal disease except
questions.explanation: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson syndrome is an insertional periostitis at the inferior pole of the patella(not associated with Renal disease).Lowe syndromeDenys-Drash SyndromeAlport syndromeSinding-Larsen-Johansson syndromeOculocerebrorenal syndrome:Hypotonia, renal diseaseAssociated withWilm's tumor:Early-onset renal failure withrenal mesangial sclerosis, male pseudohermaphroditismBilateral sensorineuralhearing loss, renal diseasePeriostitisat the inferior poleof the patella

questions.question: Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of
questions.explanation: Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of 30-300 mg/24 hrs.518Here, the presence of albumin in the urine is above the normal level but below the detectablerange for the urine-dipstick methods. It is commonly associated with glomerular hyperfiltrationand blood pressure elevation.In adults, persistent microalbuminuria indicates diabetic nephropathy and is also a predictor ofcardiovascular and renal disease.In children, microalbuminuria is associated with obesity and predicts the development of diabeticnephropathy in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness and frothy urine. Upon investigating, his urinewas positive for proteins with no hematuria and no RBC casts. To conclude the diagnosis ofnephrotic syndrome, the range of proteinuria is defined as >protein:creatinine ratio of >
questions.explanation: The currently accepted definitions of "nephrotic range proteinuria" include:••• Urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2• Urine protein > 40 mg/m2/hr• Urine protein 3+ or 4+ in dipstick testAs a consequence of the large urinary loss of protein, the patient develops hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL) and gross edema.

questions.question: 507It is expected to see all of the following clinical features in a 5-year-old boy with nephroticsyndrome except-
questions.explanation: Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome. It is a feature of nephritic syndrome.However, occasionally it is seen in the FSGS variant of nephrotic syndrome as well.Classic features of nephrotic syndrome:• Nephrotic range proteinuria ( >40mg/m2/hr urine protein: creatinine ratio >2)• Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL)• Edema• Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL)• Hypercoagulability

questions.question: What is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children?
questions.explanation: The commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. (85% ofcases).The glomeruli appear almost normal on microscopy, hence the name. Immunofluorescencemicroscopy are negative, and electron microscopy shows effacement of the epithelial cell footprocesses.Treatment: Steroids; 95% of patients respond.519Other options:• Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly; it isa rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.•Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis: All patients have asymptomatic hematuria; progressiveproteinuria is common only by the 2nd decade of life and can be severe enough to cause nephroticsyndrome. This nephrotic syndrome is not common in children.• IgA nephropathy presents more commonly as an acute nephritic syndrome or withasymptomatic hematuria. It presents with nephrotic syndrome quite rarely.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling aroundthe eyes, abdomen and feet for 2 weeks. On investigating, his urine was positive for 4+proteinuria with absent hematuria. A spot urine protein: creatinine ratio was reported to be2.5. His serum albumin was 2.3 g/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. Serum cholesteroland triglyceride levels were also elevated. A diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome was concluded.Which of the following correctly mentions the aetiology of its most common variant inchildren?
questions.explanation: Nephrotic syndrome is concluded as the diagnosis here because of the symptoms of anasarca andproteinuria. A spot urine protein:creatinine ratio >2, low serum albumin levels, andhyperlipidemia marked by high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, further add to this diagnosis.Minimal change disease is the commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children andconstitutes 85% of all paediatric cases. The etiology is due to the flattening of foot processes(podocytes) of epithelial cells (seen on electron microscopy). This finding is marked in the imagegiven below.Diffuse loss offoot processesu may have beenMicrovilliVacuolation• Here, the glomeruli appear normal or show a minimal increase in mesangial cells and matrix.••• It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.Epithelial cells, in conjunction with the basement membrane, allow the filtration of plasmasolutes but block the passage of cells and plasma proteins. Hence, this epithelial cell disease,disrupts the filtration barrier, resulting in proteinuria.•More than 95% of children with minimal change disease respond to corticosteroid therapy.Causes of epithelial cell injury:• Minimal change disease520• Membranous nephropathy• Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis• Class V lupus nephritis• Diabetic nephropathy

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?

options.A: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
options.B: Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen508
options.C: Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S

questions.explanation: Increased (and not decreased) platelet number and aggregability cause hypercoagulability innephrotic syndrome.•Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to all of the following factors:•• Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion• Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen⚫ Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S• Increased platelet number and aggregability

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy presents with facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swellinginvolving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and serumcholesterol was also elevated. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephroticsyndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seenin ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema,hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheraloedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the childfits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for thenext 6-8 weeks is recommended.Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistantpatients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:•Cyclophosphamide•Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus• Mycophenolate• Levamisole• Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

questions.question: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission afterweeks of corticosteroid therapy.
questions.explanation: 521Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks ofcorticosteroid therapy.According to the latest Indian Society of Pediatric nephrology(ISPN) guidelines, it is defined asthe absence of remission despite 6-weeks therapy with prednisolone at daily dose of 60mg/m2

questions.question: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD forvaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?

options.A: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
options.B: All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
options.C: Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
options.D: Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.explanation: In a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given.Option A: Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroidtherapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents(cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated.Option C: Only live vaccines are contraindicated in this child. Full pneumococcal vaccination (withthe 13-valent conjugate vaccine and 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine) and influenza vaccinationcan be given annually to the child and their household contacts.Option D: Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary toreduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to thegastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeksafter vaccination.Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. Itis characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Thediagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. Nephroticrange proteinuria is proteinuria greater than 3.5 g per 24 hours (3+ or 4+) or a urine protein :creatinine ratio exceeding 2.The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg)of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8weeks.Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome:• Frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome: ≥2 relapses in 6 months or 3 or more relapses in 12months.• Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks ofdiscontinuation.• Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 6weeksAlternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistantpatients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are cyclophosphamide, calcineurininhibitors: cyclosporine and Tacrolimus, mycophenolate, levamisole, and rituximab (a chimericmonoclonal antibody against CD20).

questions.question: Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting509

options.B: At birth or within 3 months of life
options.C: At birth or within 6 months of life
options.D: At birth or within 1 year of life

questions.explanation: 522Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3months of life.It may be• Primary: Due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2.•Secondary: Due to in utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis,HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupuserythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

questions.question: An 11-year-old boy with a chronic hepatitis B infection develops nephrotic syndrome. Whatwould be the most likely pathology encountered in renal biopsy of this child?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests that the pathology would be membranous nephropathy.Membranous nephropathy can be secondarily caused by Hepatitis B infection.Membranous nephropathy:Membranous nephropathy is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.• It is classified as the primary, idiopathic form, where there is an isolated renal disease, orsecondary, where nephropathy is associated with other identifiable systemic diseases ormedications• In children, secondary form is far more common. The most common etiologies of secondaryform are systemic lupus erythematosus or chronic infections. Among the latter, chronic hepatitisB infection and congenital syphilis are the best characterized and recognized causes.

questions.question: Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndrome is caused by a mutation in the
questions.explanation: Finnish type congenital nephrotic syndrome is a steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome caused bya mutation in the nephrin gene (NPHS 1)..• Affected infants usually present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria.• They are delivered with a large placenta (>25% of the infant's weight).• There is severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia.• Prenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated maternal and amniotic α-fetoprotein levels.Gene NameInheritanRenal diseaseceNPH NephrinS1Recessive Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndromeNPHPodocinRecessiveS2Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)WT1Wilms tumor-suppressor gDominanenetDenys-Drash syndrome withdiffuse mesangial sclerosis Frasier syndrome with FSGS523Gene NameLMX1BLIM-homeodomain proteinInheritanRenal diseaseceDominan Nail-patella syndromet

questions.question: FSGS is caused by mutations in thegene.
questions.explanation: • focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is caused by mutation in NPHS2 (podocin) gene.• Steroid resistant nephrotic syndrome is usually caused by FSGS (in 80% of cases).• In FSGS, glomeruli show lesions of mesangial cell proliferation and segmental scarring that areboth focal (present only in a proportion of glomeruli) and segmental (localized to ≥1intraglomerular tufts).• FSGS is associated with a 50% risk for end-stage kidney disease.Gene NameInheritanRenal diseaseceNPH NephrinS1Recessive Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndromeNPHPodocinRecessiveS2Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)WT1Wilms tumor-suppressor gDominanenetDenys-Drash syndrome withdiffuse mesangial sclerosis Frasier syndrome with FSGSLMX1BLIM-homeodomain proteinDominanNail-patella syndromet524
